intro: Perymenium tamaulipense, commonly known as the Tamaulipan perymenium, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks. Its botanical features include a slender, branching stem and white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Perymenium tamaulipense is valued for its ecological role in supporting local wildlife and its potential medicinal properties.
